text.div: No narrative is provided for definitional resources. A human-readable rendering can be found in the implementation guide(s) where this resource is used.

description.value: A condition is pathological or non-pathological state of the patient that generally presents with symptoms. It is 'that what the patient has'. A care professional can assign a (differential) diagnosis to the condition. The symptoms as well as the diagnostic insight with respect to the same condition may change over time.

purpose.value: This Condition resource represents the Dutch zib ('Zorginformatiebouwsteen', i.e. Health and Care Information Model) [Condition v1.0 (2024)](https://zibs.nl/wiki/Condition-v1.0(2024EN)).

definition.value: The course of the condition. This is independent of the diagnostic insight for the condition. The course indicates how the condition is developing: such as stable, progression, remission, etc..
The duration of the period in which the condition is (was) present in appropriate units of time (e.g. days or hours, etc.).

comment.value:
This element is implictly mapped to the zib concept NL-CM:5.4.5 (Course). Unless the clinical status of the condition is explicitly recorded, the following guidance applies:
* When the value of Course is _NTB_, _385425000_, _231877006_, _260388006_, _255314001_ or _NTB_, `.clinicalStatus` will usually be set to _active_. * When the value of Course is _350361000146109_, `.clinicalStatus` will usually be set to _inactive_. * When the value Course is 'OTH' or it attains any other value, `.clinicalStatus` has to be determined manually.

definition.value: Indication of the severity of the condition. A condition may cause few or mild symptoms and yet be serious, but the reverse is also possible.
The start date and time of the period in which the condition is (was) present.

comment.value: The zib recognizes both the StartDateTime (dateTime) and RelativeStartTime (string) concepts, whereas in FHIR only one of these concepts may be present. Therefore, if both concepts are present, it is recommended to communicate the StartDateTime as it is more precise.

definition.value: Textual representation of the start time of the period in which the condition is (was) present, associated with an event for which the time is not fixed or known. For example "Start the day after discharge from hospital".

comment.value: The zib recognizes both the StartDateTime (dateTime) and RelativeStartTime (string) concepts, whereas in FHIR only one of these concepts may be present. Therefore, if both concepts are present, it is recommended to communicate the StartDateTime as it is more precise.

definition.value: The end date and time of the period in which the condition is (was) present.

comment.value: The zib recognizes both the EndDateTime (dateTime) and RelativeEndTime (string) concepts, whereas in FHIR only one of these concepts may be present. Therefore, if both concepts are present, it is recommended to communicate the EndDateTime as it is more precise.

definition.value: Textual representation of the end time of the period in which the condition is (was) present, associated with an event for which the timing is not yet fixed. For example "Stop the day before operation".

comment.value: The zib recognizes both the EndDateTime (dateTime) and RelativeEndTime (string) concepts, whereas in FHIR only one of these concepts may be present. Therefore, if both concepts are present, it is recommended to communicate the EndDateTime as it is more precise.

definition.value: A phenomenon with which a condition in the patient presents itself. This also includes a complaint or a finding, but not additional research, such as laboratory tests, function tests and imaging studies.

comment.value: Please note that on a functional level, zib Symptom references zib Condition, but in FHIR this direction is reversed.

definition.value: A comment in free text with respect to the condition, that is not represented by the other data elements in the information model.
